These FAQs should help you know more about what you are dealing with
I am being sexually harassed now, what should I do?

- We will send a distress signal, your trusted contacts will be notified.
 - Meanwhile, follow our instructions.
 - Try to get attention to your situation by loudly asking for help and stating what happened exactly “Sexual Harassment”
 - Ask people to help you by taking him to the nearest police station and to testify while filing the official sexual harassment report.
I have been sexually harassed and I am now at the police station, what should I do?

- We will send a distress signal, your trusted contacts will be notified.
 - Meanwhile, follow our instructions.
 - You should ask for the human rights officer and explain you want to file a sexual harassment complaint.
 - Present the medical report –if you have one- and ask for it to be included in the complaint.
 - You can call Nazra for Feminist Studies for legal and psychological support: 01011910917. Nazra will send you a trained lawyer if available. 
 - Make sure to state everything that happened as is. You have the right to give your statement in a separate space than the one the harasser is held in.
 - Write down the complaint number and follow up on the investigation.
 - If someone refused to help you at the police station, call the Ministry of Interior hotline: 138 and report the incident. 
 - If you are injured and/or need a medical report, head to nearest hospital listed and ask to be directed to the emergency room, get checked out and ask for a medical report.
 - If you feel you need to talk to a professional, you can call Al-Nadeem Institute for psychological support: 01006662404 
 - You can call Nazra for Feminist Studies for psychological support: 01011910917 
 - In a couple of days, you should go to the general investigation office and you will tell your statement again with your lawyer.
I have been sexually harassed and I filed a report at the police station, what should I do?

- You can call Nazra for Feminist Studies for legal and psychological support: 01011910917. Nazra will send you a trained lawyer if available. 
 - Make sure to state everything that happened as is. You have the right to give your statement in a separate space than the one the harasser is held in.
 - Write down the complaint number and follow up on the investigation.
 - If someone refused to help you at the police station, call the Ministry of Interior hotline: 138 and report the incident. 
 - If you are injured and/or need a medical report, head to nearest hospital listed and ask to be directed to the emergency room, get checked out and ask for a medical report.
 - If you feel you need to talk to a professional, you can call Al-Nadeem Institute for psychological support: 01006662404 
 - You can call Nazra for Feminist Studies for psychological support: 01011910917 
 - In a couple of days, you should go to the general investigation office and you will tell your statement again with your lawyer.
 - Follow your lawyer’s instructions and don’t ever take back you statement. 
 - If you are threatened or harassed by the family of the harasser, communicate with your lawyer and file a restraining order against them.
 - Follow up with your case number until the case reaches courts and the harasser gets a sentence.
I have been sexually harassed and I have physical injuries, what should I do?

- We will send a distress signal, your trusted contacts will be notified.
 - Meanwhile, follow our instructions.
 - If you are hurt and need medical attention please, head to the nearest hospital to get medical help and file a medical report.
 - You can always go to the nearest police station and file and official “Sexual Harassment” Complaint.
I have been sexually harassed and I need to talk to someone, what should I do?

- We will send a distress signal, your trusted contacts will be notified.
 - Meanwhile, follow our instructions.
 - If you are hurt and need medical attention please, head to the nearest hospital to get medical help and file a medical report.
 - You can always go to the nearest police station and file and official “Sexual Harassment” Complaint.
I don\'t know what to do
I am now at the police station, what should i do?
I filed a report at the police station, what should i do?
I have physical injuries, what should i do?
I need to talk to someone, what should i do?
Hey,I am your street pal. \n What is wrong?
I think I am being followed by someone
Do your surroundings feel safe? Do you think people around you might help?
Confront the possible threat and establish eye contact
Remember your voice is a very powerful weapon, so use it more
You can inquire in a direct and firm tone by asking: “Is something wrong? - You keep looking at me, do I know you?
Remember, your safety comes first. You DO NOT have to do anything that might endanger you.
We are glad you are safe and sound, please, share your experience and tell your story so that you can help others.
We will navigate you to full guide, Tap Go To Guide below
We are going to send an alert to your trusted contacts to notify them about your situation
If the situation changed, please tell us what is happening

Study your surroundings and scan for people who might help or places you might seek for shelter. If you are not in an isolated space and you believe there are people around that might help click YES, if not click NO
Try to get yourself away from the threat and through a populated area.
If you can’t do so we recommend you make your way to the nearest safe place, we will draw you a route if you click here
Be ready to follow our guide if something happened
We can alert your trusted contact that you feel worried, by clicking here
Study your surroundings and scan for people who might help or places you might seek for shelter
If you are not in an isolated space and you believe there are people around that might help click YES, if not click NO
We are sending a distress signal, your trusted contacts are being notified
Try to get attention to your situation by loudly asking for help and stating what happened exactly “Sexual Harassment”
Ask people to help you by taking him to the nearest police station and to testify while filing the official sexual harassment report
Did people respond and help? Are you heading to the police station?
No, and I can’t take him to the police station
Yes, they are helping but they are not taking him to the police station
Yes, they are helping and we are heading to the police station now
Try and recognize details about the harasser
Get yourself to safety, If you are hurt and need medical attention please, head to <u>the nearest hospital</u> to get medical help and file a medical report
If you are hurt and need medical attention please, head to <u>the nearest hospital</u> to get medical help and file a medical report
You can always go to <u>the nearest police station</u> and file an official “Sexual Harassment” Complaint
Ask people again to help you take the harasser to the police station and explain that this is the right way to handle the situation
If you succeed and they are helping you get to the police station, click here: <u>Yes, they are helping and we are heading to the police station now</u>
If they still won’t help you get to the police station, do the following
If you feel unsafe, Get yourself to safety, If you are hurt and need medical attention please, head to <u>the nearest hospital</u> to get medical help and file a medical report
Ask people to testify with you in the police station and explain that this is the right way to handle the situation
Head to <u>the nearest police station</u> and file an official “Sexual Harassment” Complaint
Follow the route to <u>the nearest police station</u> to file an official “Sexual Harassment” Complaint
Upon arrival ask for the human rights officer and explain you want to file a sexual harassment complaint
Present the medical report –if you have one- and ask for it to be included in the complaint
You can call Nazra for Feminist Studies for legal and psychological support: <u>01011910917</u> . Nazra will send you a trained lawyer if available
Make sure to state everything that happened as is. You have the right to give your statement in a separate space than the one the harasser is held in
Make sure to state everything that happened as is. And YES, you can file a complaint even if the harasser is not caught
Write down the complaint number and follow up on the investigation
Make sure to describe the harasser as best you can
If someone refused to help you at the police station, call the Ministry of Interior hotline: 138 and report the incident.
If you feel you need to talk to a professional, you can call Al-Nadeem Institute for psychological support: <u>01006662404</u>
You can call Nazra for Feminist Studies for psychological support: <u>01011910917</u>
In a couple of days, you should go to the general investigation office and you will tell your statement again with your lawyer
If you are injured and/or need a medical report, head to <u>nearest hospital</u> listed and ask to be directed to the emergency room, get checked out and ask for a medical report
Follow your lawyer’s instructions and don’t ever take back you statement
If you are threatened or harassed by the family of the harasser, communicate with your lawyer and file a restraining order against them
Follow up with your case number until the case reaches courts and the harasser gets a sentence
Head to <u>nearest hospital</u> listed and ask to be directed to the emergency room, get checked out and ask for a medical report
If you feel able, you should head to the nearest police station and file and official “Sexual Harassment” Complaint
Present the medical report and ask for it to be included in the complaint
You can call Nazra for Feminist Studies for legal and psychological support: <u>01011910917</u>
Follow the route to <u>the nearest police station </u>and file an official “Sexual Harassment” Complaint
If you feel you are not able to do this, you can always file a report on the phone by calling the Ministry of Interior hotline: 138
Remember you have done nothing wrong and you have the right to speak about what happened whenever you feel you can
Try and remember details about the harasser
You can educate yourself through my library or seek instant guidance when needed by clicking below.
and I am here to help you stand up for yourself.

If you have any questions about these Terms, please contact us on info@streetpal.org

We reserve the right, at our sole discretion, to modify or replace these Terms at any time. If a revision is necessary, we will provide notice of the terms taking effect. What constitutes a material change will be determined at our sole discrebtion.

Our Service allows you to post, link, store, share and otherwise make available certain information, text, graphics, videos, or other material ("Content"). You are responsible for the information provided and on our part, we are obliged to share information with authorities pending a formal inquiry within an official investigation and only in this case.
Our Service may contain links to third-partyweb sites or services that are not owned or controlled by StreetPal®. StreetPal® has no control over, and assumes no responsibility for, the content, privacy policies, or practices of any third party web sites or services. You further acknowledge and agree that StreetPal® shall not be responsible or liable, directly or indirectly, for any damage or loss caused or alleged to be caused by or in connection with use of or reliance on any such content, goods or services available on or through any such web sites or services.
Content of sign up and trusted contacts.

StreetPal® offers comprehensive information critical to handling different real-life situations that are very fluid and have no fixed scenarios. All information and guidance provided are modulated upon best practices and common cases and situations. The service aims to educate and guide a majority of people towards proper conduct in real-life situations that may be –on some occasions- life-threatening. By accepting these terms, you confirm that as a user, you will use the information provided –at your own risk- as recommendations and not as code of conduct and that you will take full responsibility for your actions and their results. This service is in no way a replacement for your common sense and better judgement. You should always choose what to do at any certain situations and we will do our best to provide you with more options as we can.
Some parts of the Service are billed on a subscription basis ("Subscription(s)"). You will be billed in advance yearly. However, this service will be always free of charge in Egypt.
By accessing or using the Service, you agree to be bound by these Terms. If you disagree with any part of the terms then you may not access the Service.

Last updated: (August, 19, 2017) Please read these Terms and Conditions ("Terms", "Terms and Conditions") carefully before using The StreetPal® website www.streetpal.org and the StreetPal® mobile application operated by Smart Civic Solutions Company. Your access to and use of the Service is conditioned on your acceptance of and compliance with these Terms. These Terms apply to all visitors, users and others who access or use the Service.
StreetPal® Terms and Conditions Terms and Conditions ("Terms")
- Guide to relevant entities for legal and psychological help.
- Navigation to safe places, Police station and hospital.
- Smart guide -in steps- on what to do when subjected to or witness sexual harassment
- Increase awareness about sexual violence and sexual harassment
- Effective guidance of sexual harassment victims towards proper conduct

StreetPal® is smart application platform aims at building a community of well-trained advocates who are able to help spread awareness about sexual harassment and effectively take part in combating the crime through the current national legal framework. All by gathering common practices and solutions in a smart and easy compact tool introducing a new comprehensive and interactive guide on how to combat sexual harassment using technology.

resources.string: has been harrassed/feel danger and need help. she/he is heading to hospiatal/ police station you can check the location by

Sexual harassment is:

 Any form of unwanted words and/or actions of a sexual nature that violate a person’s body, privacy, or feelings and make that person feel uncomfortable, threatened, insecure, scared, disrespected, startled, insulted, intimidated, abused, offended, or objectified.

 Sexual harassment can take many different forms and include one or more types at one time:

 - Ogling: Staring or looking inappropriately at someone’s body, body parts, and/or eyes.
 - Facial expressions: Making any kind of facial expression (licking, winking, and opening the mouth) that suggest sexual intentions.
 - Catcalls: Whistling, shouting, whispering, and any kind of sexually suggestive sounds/noises.
 - Comments: Sexual remarks about someone’s body or clothes or way of walking/behaving/working, telling sexual jokes or stories, suggestions that are sexual or offensive.
 - Stalking or following: Following someone, close or at a distance, by foot or in a car, repeatedly or just once, or waiting outside someone’s work/home/car etc.
- Sexual invites: Asking for sex, describing sexual acts or wishes, asking for phone numbers, dinner dates and other suggestions that are implicitly or explicitly sexual in nature.
 - Unwanted attention: Interfering with someone’s work or actions by seeking unwelcome contact, asking to socialize, making sexual demands in exchange for work or other benefits, giving gifts that are sexually suggestive, insisting on walking/driving someone home or to work in spite of refusal from the other person.
 - Sexual photos: Showing sexual or private photos or pictures online or offline.
 - Online: Repeatedly or occasionally sending unwanted, abusive, or obscene messages, comments, and/or photos and videos via email, instant messaging, on social media, forums, blogs, or online discussion boards.
 - Phone calls: Making unwanted phone calls or sending text messages that are sexually suggestive or threatening.
 - Touching: Unwanted touching, massaging, pinching, rubbing up against, standing too close, grabbing, groping and any kind of unwanted sexual gesture towards someone.
 - Indecent exposure: Showing intimate body parts to someone, or masturbating in front of someone or in someone’s presence.
 - Threat: Threatening with any form of sexual harassment and/or assault (including rape).
 - Mob sexual harassment: Sexual harassment (any of the above categories) committed by large groups of people against one or more individuals.

 Sexual harassment is a form of sexual violence. Other forms include:

 - Sexual assault: Coerced and/or forced sexual acts such as kissing, undressing etc.
 - Rape: Coerced and/or forced oral, anal, or vaginal penetration using body parts or other objects.
 - Mob sexual assault/rape: Sexual assault (including rape), committed by large groups of people against one or more individuals.
 
 Where does it happen?
 
 Sexual harassment and other forms of sexual violence can take place anywhere, in both public and in private places, for example: the street, workplaces, public transportation, schools and universities, restaurants, malls, at home, in the company of others (family, relatives, and colleagues), online etc.

 Who is the harasser?

 Harassers/perpetrators of sexual violence can be individuals or groups of men and/or women. The harasser can be a complete stranger or someone you know: an employer, employee, co-worker, customer, passerby, relative, family member, or a guest. The harassed can be individuals and groups of all kinds of women and/or men.

 Important:

 - Sexual harassment is never okay.
 - It is never up to the harasser to decide what counts as harassment and what does not.
 - Sexual harassment is a crime .
 - Sexual harassment is never the fault of the harassed. To harass someone is a choice the harasser makes and regardless of what the harassed is wearing or doing, and this is never an excuse for harassment . It is easy – the harassed is never, partially or fully, responsible for any sexual harassment that they are subjected to.

 All rights reserved to HarassMap 2015
 http://harassmap.org/en/resource-center/what-is-sexual-harassment/
